revisions.*:
'''Harry Clinton Gossard''' (1884–1954) was an American educator and [[geometer]]. He is credited with the discovery of a then unknown [[triangle center]] in 1916 to which [[John Horton Conway|John Conway]] assigned the name [[Gossard perspector]] in 1998.<ref name=Clark>{{cite web|last=Kimberling|first=Clark|title=Harry Clinton Gossard|url=http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/bstud/gossard.html|accessdate=17 June 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Kimberling|first=Clark|title=Gossard Perspector|url=http://faculty.evansville.edu/ck6/tcenters/recent/gosspersp.html|accessdate=17 June 2012}}</ref>   

After receiving his Ph. D. from [[Johns Hopkins University]] in 1912, Gossard taught at [[University of Oklahoma]] (1912–1916), the [[U. S. Naval Academy]] (1916–18),  University of Oklahoma (1918–19), [[University of Wyoming]] (1921–25), and [[Nebraska Wesleyan University]] (1926–31). During the period 1931 to 1939, Gossard was President of New Mexico Normal University (now [[Highlands University]]), and during 1939 to 1950, he was Dean of Eastern New Mexico College (now [[Eastern New Mexico University]]). He worked for the US State Department during the last four years of his life.<ref name=Clark/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://mathforum.org/kb/message.jspa?messageID=1177087|title=Math Forum : Historia Mathematica message|publisher=Drexel University|accessdate=17 June 2012}}</ref>
